Summary: The proposal aims to improve the sample efficiency of reinforcement learning (RL) by integrating adaptive model-based priors that dynamically adjust their influence on policy optimization based on uncertainty. The method combines uncertainty-adaptive models, hierarchical policy decomposition, and directed curiosity, with a comprehensive experiment plan covering synthetic tasks, benchmark comparisons, long-horizon tasks, sparse-reward environments, and real-world transfer.
Strengths: Innovative combination of uncertainty-adaptive models, hierarchical policy decomposition, and directed curiosity.
Strong potential for impact given the critical bottleneck of sample inefficiency in RL.
Weaknesses: Lacks detailed discussion of potential technical challenges and risks.
Could provide clearer justification for the choice of baselines and evaluation metrics.
Real-world transfer experiments are ambitious and may face unforeseen practical challenges.
Questions: How will the gating mechanism be implemented to ensure it scales the influence of model-based gradients proportionally to the model’s confidence?
What are the specific metrics for evaluating the success of the hierarchical policy decomposition in long-horizon tasks?
How will the directed curiosity module avoid redundant or unsafe exploration in practice?
How will the computational overhead of ensemble models be managed?
What are the failure modes of the gating mechanism in highly stochastic environments?
Limitations: The proposed method may face challenges in scaling to very high-dimensional state spaces.
The real-world transfer experiments may be limited by the availability of suitable robotic platforms and environments.
The directed curiosity module may introduce additional computational overhead.
Robustness of gating mechanism in highly stochastic environments.
Complexity of sim-to-real transfer may limit real-world applicability.
